title: Three for the Road: Mt. Tam, Murphys and Santa Ynez Valley
text:
CARLESS GETAWAY
Mount Tamalpais: hiking and eating
Make a visit to Mount Tamalpais last all weekend long, instead of struggling to get home after a full day of hiking. Staying overnight also allows you a more relaxed appreciation of Mount Tam, and avoids an early morning car trip to see the sunrise. 
Get there: From San Francisco, take the Golden Gate Ferry to Sausalito. From there, the Marin Stagecoach bus transports you to stops on Mount Tam. Total round-trip fare for both: about $26.50.
Doze: The Mountain Home Inn is just across Panoramic Highway from the top of the Panoramic Trail and steps from hiking trails on Mount Tamalpais. 810 Panoramic Highway; (415) 381-9000; www.mtnhomeinn.com. Rates start at $195.
Dine: Molina, in Mill Valley at the foot of the mountain, serves rustic and sublime cuisine that’s the perfect end to a day in the great outdoors. 17 Madrona St.; (415) 383-4200; www.molinarestaurant.com. 
Do: Visit the East Peak Visitor Center , where you can discover the railroad history of Mount Tamalpais, learn about local flora and fauna, or sign up for a guided hike.
Good to know: April through October, astronomy nights take place at the Mountain Theater and include lectures by astronomers and a Night Sky Tour.
ONE-TANK WONDER
Murphys: caving and wine tasting
The town of Murphys is known to Gold Rush historians as having been one of the state’s richest “diggins.” But this small town is becoming known as a wine destination, where boutique wineries are particularly welcoming of visitors seeking tasting and tours. Add in a little exercise discovering one of the local caves, and you won’t feel guilty about sitting and drinking the rest of the weekend. 
Get there: 141 miles from downtown San Francisco on Interstate 580 and Highway 4.
Doze: Victoria Inn includes continental breakfast and free Wi-Fi, and its location on Main Street means you can walk to taste wine. 402 Main St., H; (209) 728-8933; www.victoriainn-murphys.com. Rates start at $129.
Dine: A local favorite with an outdoor patio, Grounds has enough great food to support a few hours of wine sampling. 402 Main St., Suite A; (209) 728-8663; www.groundsrestaurant.com. 
Do: Go underground on a 45-minute guided tour of Mercer Caverns, although due to the need to climb stairs, it’s probably best done before your wine tasting.
Good to know: Most of Murphys’ wine tasting rooms are conveniently located within walking distance of each other on elm-shaded Main Street. Don’t skip Hatcher and Newsome Harlow on your self-guided tour.
FARTHER AFIELD
Santa Ynez Valley: 
Cowboys and barbecue
Solvang is known for its Danish village, but just a short distance out of town, you’ll run into a guest ranch that will satisfy your cowboy dreams — but with top-notch cuisine and a comfortable bed at night. Dodge between both “cultures” during your stay, but the relaxation at Alisal is what will draw you back. 
Get there: Drive 297 miles south on Highway 101 to Solvang.
Doze: The Old West-style 10,000-acre Alisal Guest Ranch and Resort has 50 miles of riding trails (and plenty of horses), two 18-hole golf courses and tennis courts, and is within reach of great wine-producing vineyards. 1054 S. Alisal Road; (805) 688-6411; www.alisal.com. Rates start at $525 for two.
Dine: Drop by the Hitching Post II in nearby Buellton for some of the best Santa Maria-style barbecue in the region. 406 E. Highway 246; (805) 688-0676; www.hitchingpost2.com. 
Do: Have a Western-style ride to breakfast at Alisal’s Adobe Camp, where sycamore trees and a crackling campfire provide a backdrop for your tasty flapjacks.
Good to know: The region is well known for its wine, but there’s also a big craft beer movement here. Pick up the Craft Beer Trail Map in town and taste a few brews.
